claim.text: We show that combining tabular data from financial semi-structured documents with text transcripts and audio recordings improves stock volatility and price movement prediction by 5-12% along with reduction in gender bias learned by audio-based neural networks by over 30%.
claim.exact_quote: We show that combining tabular data from financial semi-structured documents with text transcripts and audio recordings improves stock volatility and price movement prediction by 5-12% along with reduction in gender bias learned by audio-based neural networks by over 30%.

evidence.evidence_text: We show that combining tabular data from financial semi-structured documents with text transcripts and audio recordings improves stock volatility and price movement prediction by 5-12% along with reduction in gender bias learned by audio-based neural networks by over 30%.
evidence.exact_quote: We show that combining tabular data from financial semi-structured documents with text transcripts and audio recordings improves stock volatility and price movement prediction by 5-12% along with reduction in gender bias learned by audio-based neural networks by over 30%.

conclusion.key_limitations: The claim is supported by empirical results showing improvements in stock volatility and price movement prediction, as well as a reduction in gender bias.

claim.text: We demonstrate that supplementing existing conference calls transcripts with the tabular financial data substantially reduces the unintended gender bias in financial prediction tasks and offers a robust and unbiased alternative to gender-sensitive audio features in cases where under-representation of women speakers induces unneeded correlations in model predictions.
claim.exact_quote: We demonstrate that supplementing existing conference calls transcripts with the tabular financial data substantially reduces the unintended gender bias in financial prediction tasks and offers a robust and unbiased alternative to gender-sensitive audio features in cases where under-representation of women speakers induces unneeded correlations in model predictions.

conclusion.key_limitations: The claim is supported by empirical results showing the reduction in unintended gender bias in financial prediction tasks.

claim.text: We combine publicly available earnings calls and M&A calls datasets with tabular data extracted from SEC-EDGAR 10-Q and 10-K company-filing documents.

claim.text: We utilize tabular information from financial semi-structured documents with existing textual and audio modalities to show 8-12% relative improvement in stock volatility and price movement prediction tasks across several baseline and state-of-the-art models.
claim.exact_quote: We utilize tabular information from financial semi-structured documents with existing textual and audio modalities to show 8-12% relative improvement in stock volatility and price movement prediction tasks across several baseline and state-of-the-art models.

evidence.evidence_text: We utilize tabular information from financial semi-structured documents with existing textual and audio modalities to show 8-12% relative improvement in stock volatility and price movement prediction tasks across several baseline and state-of-the-art models.

conclusion.key_limitations: The claim is supported by empirical results showing improvements in stock volatility and price movement prediction across several baseline and state-of-the-art models.

claim.text: We empirically show the extent of induced gender bias due to audio modality in the financial prediction models and demonstrate the usefulness of tabular data extracted from semistructured financial documents as an alternative to audio modality for reducing gender bias by 30% in audio-based neural networks, without significant performance degradation.
claim.exact_quote: We empirically show the extent of induced gender bias due to audio modality in the financial prediction models and demonstrate the usefulness of tabular data extracted from semistructured financial documents as an alternative to audio modality for reducing gender bias by 30% in audio-based neural networks, without significant performance degradation.

evidence.evidence_text: We empirically show the extent of induced gender bias due to audio modality in the financial prediction models and demonstrate the usefulness of tabular data extracted from semistructured financial documents as an alternative to audio modality for reducing gender bias by 30% in audio-based neural networks, without significant performance degradation.
evidence.exact_quote: We empirically show the extent of induced gender bias due to audio modality in the financial prediction models and demonstrate the usefulness of tabular data extracted from semistructured financial documents as an alternative to audio modality for reducing gender bias by 30% in audio-based neural networks, without significant performance degradation.

conclusion.key_limitations: The claim is supported by empirical results showing the reduction in gender bias due to the use of tabular data.
